summary: in eukaryotic cells, the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is the major site where secreted and transmembrane proteins are synthesized and folded. unfolded proteins accumulate in the ER lumen and cause ER stress. to maintain homeostasis, signaling pathways collectively known as the unfolded-protein response (UPR) are activated (1). BP1 (XBP1u) mRNA encodes an inhibitor of the UPR. XBP1s mRNA encodes a potent transcription activator, which translocates to the nucleus and enhances the expression of many UPR genes. ER homeostasis is a highly controlled mode of cell death characterized by cell shrinkage, plasma membrane blebbing, and nuclear fragmentation. ire1-XBP1 pathway inhibits apoptosis in late-stage infected cells. ire1 protected infected cells from IBV-induced apoptosis. the mechanism regulating this process remains largely unexplored. prosurvival kinase Akt was also modulated by IRE1 to promote
